An outbreak of cholera has struck Haiti nine months after a devastating earthquake.
More than a hundred people have died and more than 1,000 have become sick.
So far, the outbreak has not reached the camps in Port-au-Prince that shelter hundreds of thousands of people who lost their homes in the earthquake.
As NPR's Jon Hamilton reports, public health officials are working hard to keep the disease from spreading to the capital.
The outbreak began in an area about 60 or 70 miles north of Port-au-Prince.
Dr. Michel Thieren is with the Pan American Health Organization in Haiti.
He says hospitals near the outbreak have been overwhelmed, with some setting up outdoor treatment areas.
But Thieren says at this point, it's hard to know how many people are sick.
What we know now is that it is an epidemic that is accompanied to the high mortality rate.
We have about 10 percent (unintelligible) fatality rate.
Cholera kills by causing diarrhea and vomiting so severe that people become dangerously dehydrated.
It is spread when food or water becomes contaminated with a bacteria that infects the intestines.
Thieren says it's not clear why this outbreak occurred in a nation that hasn't seen cholera for decades.
It is misleading to associate this earthquake with the occurrence of the disease that have nothing to do with one or another.
Thieren says now that cholera has appeared, the camps around Port-au-Prince are especially vulnerable.
That's because people live in poverty and enclosed quarters, often without adequate sanitation, and sometimes, without clean drinking water.
The conditions are (unintelligible) of about a million, a million and a half (unintelligible) population in precarious conditions.
This is never good news for waterborne disease epidemics.
